title: Carotid Stenosis
icd10: ** I65.29 (Occlusion and stenosis of unspecified carotid artery)
I65.21 (Occlusion and stenosis of right carotid artery)
I65.22 (Occlusion and stenosis of left carotid artery)
I65.23 (Occlusion and stenosis of bilateral carotid arteries)
I63.131 (Cerebral infarction due to embolism of right carotid artery)
I63.132 (Cerebral infarction due to embolism of left carotid artery)
I63.031 (Cerebral infarction due to thrombosis of right carotid artery)

scope: ** Evaluation and management of extracranial internal carotid artery stenosis, including symptomatic (TIA/stroke within 6 months) and asymptomatic classification, medical optimization (antiplatelet, statin, blood pressure management), risk stratification, indications for carotid endarterectomy (CEA) versus carotid artery stenting (CAS), perioperative management, and long-term surveillance. Covers NASCET, ACAS, ACST, CREST, and CREST-2 trial data. Excludes intracranial stenosis (see intracranial atherosclerosis template), vertebrobasilar stenosis, carotid dissection (see cervical artery dissection template), fibromuscular dysplasia, carotid body tumors, and radiation-induced carotid disease.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline for statin optimization; LDL target <70 mg/dL for secondary prevention in all carotid stenosis patients; reassess 6 weeks after statin initiation
Diabetes is a major modifiable risk factor for carotid atherosclerosis progression; diabetes worsens perioperative outcomes for CEA/CAS
Essential/Core Labs.target: <7% for most; <6.5% if newly diagnosed; >6.5% confirms diabetes

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline for antiplatelet therapy and surgical planning; anemia worsens cerebral ischemia; thrombocytosis increases thrombotic risk; preoperative requirement for CEA/CAS
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; Hgb >10; plt >100K for anticoagulation; >50K for antiplatelet

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function for contrast dye planning (CTA, angiography); electrolytes; hepatic function for statin safety; glucose; preoperative baseline for CEA/CAS
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; creatinine for contrast risk; eGFR >30 for contrast; LFTs for statin safety

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulation baseline; preoperative requirement for CEA; concurrent anticoagulation assessment; hemorrhagic risk stratification
Essential/Core Labs.target: INR <1.5 for surgery; therapeutic INR 2-3 if on warfarin for concurrent AF

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes screening and monitoring; hyperglycemia worsens ischemic outcomes; perioperative glucose management
Thyroid disease contributes to atherosclerosis; hypothyroidism worsens hyperlipidemia; hyperthyroidism may cause atrial fibrillation (concurrent embolic source)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; abnormal TSH warrants further evaluation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Independent cardiovascular risk factor; elevated Lp(a) accelerates carotid atherosclerosis; if elevated, add PCSK9 inhibitor for intensified lipid lowering
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <50 nmol/L; elevated warrants intensified lipid therapy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Better predictor of residual cardiovascular risk than LDL alone; useful when LDL at goal but residual risk persists; reflects total atherogenic particle burden
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <70 mg/dL; elevated warrants intensified lipid therapy

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hyperhomocysteinemia is an independent risk factor for carotid atherosclerosis; screen if young patient or accelerated disease without traditional risk factors
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <15 micromol/L; elevated warrants B12, folate, B6 supplementation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Inflammatory biomarker; elevated hs-CRP in carotid stenosis patients indicates higher cardiovascular event risk; guides intensity of medical therapy; JUPITER trial supports statin use with elevated CRP
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <2 mg/L; elevated warrants aggressive medical optimization

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Heart failure screening; preoperative cardiac risk assessment for CEA/CAS; elevated in concurrent cardiac disease
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal for age; elevated warrants echocardiogram and cardiology evaluation

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Preoperative requirement for CEA; blood availability in case of intraoperative hemorrhage or neck hematoma
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Type and antibody screen available; crossmatch if complex antibodies

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Perioperative MI screening; concurrent coronary artery disease evaluation in symptomatic carotid patients; acute coronary syndrome exclusion
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal; elevated warrants cardiology evaluation and delays elective CEA/CAS

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Young patient (<50) with carotid stenosis and no traditional risk factors; recurrent events despite optimal medical therapy; protein C, protein S, antithrombin III, factor V Leiden, prothrombin G20210A
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; positive warrants hematology referral and adjustment of antithrombotic therapy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Young patient with carotid stenosis or thrombosis without typical atherosclerotic risk factors; lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-beta2-glycoprotein I (confirm at 12 weeks)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; positive (confirmed at 12 weeks) warrants anticoagulation per APS guidelines

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If vasculitis suspected (Takayasu arteritis, giant cell arteritis) as alternative etiology for carotid stenosis rather than atherosclerosis; atypical distribution or age
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal; elevated warrants vasculitis workup and temporal artery biopsy if applicable

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Fructosamine if HbA1c unreliable (hemoglobinopathy, recent transfusion, hemolytic anemia); reflects 2-3 week glucose average

Essential/First-line.timing: Initial screening and grading tool; within 24 hours if symptomatic (TIA/stroke); annual surveillance if known stenosis
Essential/First-line.target: NASCET-method stenosis grading: <50% (medical only); 50-69% (consider CEA if symptomatic); 70-99% (CEA/CAS strongly recommended if symptomatic); PSV >125 cm/s = >50%; PSV >230 cm/s = >70%; ICA/CCA ratio >4.0 = >70%
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None; operator-dependent; limited by calcification, high bifurcation, or body habitus

Essential/First-line.timing: All symptomatic carotid stenosis patients; evaluate for acute/subacute infarction; silent infarcts on DWI increase stroke risk even in asymptomatic stenosis; pre-intervention baseline
Essential/First-line.target: No acute infarct (asymptomatic); acute DWI-positive lesion ipsilateral to stenosis (symptomatic); chronic white matter disease
Essential/First-line.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; severe claustrophobia; use CT head if MRI not available

Essential/First-line.timing: Confirmatory vascular imaging when duplex shows significant stenosis; better anatomic detail of plaque morphology, stenosis length, and aortic arch anatomy for surgical planning; circle of Willis and collateral assessment
Essential/First-line.target: Degree and length of stenosis; ulcerated vs smooth plaque; calcification pattern; aortic arch type (I/II/III); bovine arch; tandem lesions; intracranial collaterals
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy (premedicate); renal insufficiency (eGFR <30 relative; hydrate); pregnancy

Essential/First-line.timing: Atrial fibrillation detection (concurrent embolic source); baseline cardiac rhythm; preoperative requirement; MI screening in patients with concurrent coronary disease
Essential/First-line.target: Normal sinus rhythm; AF warrants anticoagulation decision independent of carotid management; ST/T changes warrant cardiology evaluation

Essential/First-line.timing: Assess cardiac function preoperatively; identify concurrent embolic sources (LV thrombus, valvular disease, PFO); EF assessment for perioperative risk stratification
Essential/First-line.target: Normal EF (>55%); no intracardiac thrombus; no significant valvular disease; EF <30% increases perioperative risk

Extended.timing: Alternative to CTA when contrast is contraindicated (renal insufficiency, contrast allergy); may overestimate stenosis degree by 10-15% compared to angiography; time-of-flight (TOF) or contrast-enhanced
Extended.target: Stenosis degree (tends to overestimate); flow gaps suggest critical stenosis; intracranial collateral assessment
Extended.contraindications: MRI-incompatible implants; claustrophobia; gadolinium contraindicated if eGFR <30 (nephrogenic systemic fibrosis)

Extended.timing: If symptomatic stenosis with question of hemodynamic compromise; assess cerebrovascular reserve; guide urgency of intervention; identify misery perfusion
Extended.target: Normal perfusion (adequate collaterals) vs decreased perfusion (hemodynamic compromise — increases urgency of revascularization); elevated Tmax; decreased CBF
Extended.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal insufficiency; radiation exposure

Extended.timing: Paroxysmal AF detection in symptomatic carotid stenosis patients; concurrent cardiac arrhythmia changes management from antiplatelet to anticoagulation
Extended.target: Normal sinus rhythm; paroxysmal AF warrants anticoagulation

Extended.item: Transcranial Doppler with microembolic signal detection (CPT 93886)
Extended.timing: Identify active microemboli from carotid plaque (unstable plaque marker); assess intracranial collateral flow through circle of Willis; vasomotor reactivity testing for hemodynamic reserve; higher microembolic signals predict increased stroke risk
Extended.target: No microembolic signals (stable plaque); HITS (high-intensity transient signals) indicate active embolization and unstable plaque; adequate collateral flow via ACA cross-flow

Extended.timing: High-resolution MRI to characterize plaque composition; identify vulnerable plaque features (lipid-rich necrotic core, intraplaque hemorrhage, thin/ruptured fibrous cap); guides intervention in moderate stenosis
Extended.target: Stable fibrous plaque (lower risk); intraplaque hemorrhage or thin fibrous cap (high risk — favors intervention even at moderate stenosis)

Rare/Specialized.timing: Gold standard for stenosis measurement (NASCET method); when non-invasive imaging is discordant or inconclusive; pre-intervention planning for complex anatomy; evaluate tandem intracranial lesions
Rare/Specialized.target: Exact stenosis percentage (NASCET: distal ICA ratio); collateral flow; ulcerated plaque; string sign (near-occlusion); tandem lesions
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Invasive; stroke risk 0.5-1%; contrast allergy; renal insufficiency; coagulopathy; groin complications

Rare/Specialized.timing: Research and emerging clinical tool for identifying metabolically active (inflamed) carotid plaque; identifies high-risk plaque beyond degree of stenosis; not yet standard of care
Rare/Specialized.target: Low FDG uptake (quiescent plaque) vs high uptake (inflamed, unstable plaque — higher stroke risk)
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Radiation; cost; availability; not validated for clinical decision-making

Rare/Specialized.timing: Evaluate cerebral hemodynamic compromise in chronic carotid occlusion; stage II hemodynamic failure (increased OEF) predicts higher ipsilateral stroke risk; guides bypass surgery consideration
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal OEF (adequate perfusion); elevated OEF (misery perfusion — hemodynamic compromise; evaluate for EC-IC bypass in select cases per COSS trial data)
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: PET availability; radiation; cost; not routine

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: First-line antiplatelet for all carotid stenosis patients (symptomatic and asymptomatic); lifelong secondary prevention; reduces stroke risk 22% in symptomatic patients

dosing.instructions: 81 mg PO daily (preferred long-term); 325 mg for first 3 months if symptomatic or perioperative; lifelong therapy

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Active GI bleeding; aspirin allergy; thrombocytopenia <50K; concurrent full-dose anticoagulation (use one or other)
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: GI symptoms; bleeding signs; annual CBC; GI prophylaxis with PPI if high-risk

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: Alternative to aspirin if aspirin-intolerant; component of DAPT for 21 days after minor stroke/TIA per CHANCE/POINT; perioperative use with CEA

dosing.instructions: 75 mg PO daily; 300 mg loading dose for acute minor stroke; monotherapy if aspirin-intolerant; lifelong antiplatelet required

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Active bleeding; CYP2C19 poor metabolizer (reduced efficacy — use ticagrelor); thrombocytopenia; concurrent anticoagulation
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: Bleeding signs; CYP2C19 genotyping if available; platelet function testing rarely needed; hold 5-7 days before CEA if on DAPT

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: Dual antiplatelet x 21 days for minor ischemic stroke (NIHSS <=3) or high-risk TIA (ABCD2 >=4) per CHANCE/POINT trials; periprocedural for CAS (30-day minimum DAPT required)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Aspirin + Clopidogrel (DAPT — short-term) 81 mg + 75 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg (with 300 mg clopidogrel load) x 21 days from symptom onset then monotherapy; for CAS: DAPT x 30 days minimum (some continue 3-6 months); DO NOT continue long-term DAPT beyond 90 days for stroke (increases bleeding)
dosing.orderSentence: Aspirin + Clopidogrel (DAPT — short-term) 81 mg + 75 mg PO

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Major bleeding; planned CEA within 5-7 days (hold clopidogrel); thrombocytopenia; high bleeding risk
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: Bleeding signs closely during DAPT period; GI prophylaxis with PPI if high GI risk; platelet count

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: High-intensity statin for ALL carotid stenosis patients regardless of LDL; reduces cardiovascular events; plaque stabilization and possible regression; SPARCL trial supports LDL <70 for secondary prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 40-80 mg daily; target LDL <70 mg/dL; 80 mg preferred for symptomatic carotid stenosis; plaque regression observed with intensive statin therapy

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; concurrent strong CYP3A4 inhibitors at high doses; unexplained persistent transaminase elevation
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: LFTs at baseline and 3 months; CK if myalgia; lipid panel q3-6 months until at goal then annually

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: High-intensity statin alternative to atorvastatin; more potent LDL lowering per mg; non-CYP3A4 metabolism avoids drug interactions

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg daily; increase to 40 mg if needed; max 40 mg; preferred if CYP3A4 drug interactions a concern; target LDL <70 mg/dL

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; severe renal impairment (max 10 mg if CrCl <30)
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: LFTs at baseline and 3 months; CK if myalgia; lipid panel q3-6 months; Asian patients: start 5-10 mg (increased levels)

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: Add-on to statin if LDL not at goal on maximum tolerated statin; IMPROVE-IT trial showed benefit in secondary prevention; contributes to plaque regression when combined with statin

dosing.instructions: 10 mg PO daily; add to any statin; no dose adjustment needed

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment (when combined with statin); hypersensitivity
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: Lipid panel q3 months after starting until at goal; LFTs with statin combination

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: Add-on if LDL not at goal (<70 mg/dL) despite maximum tolerated statin + ezetimibe; FOURIER trial showed cardiovascular event reduction; indicated for high-risk atherosclerotic disease including carotid stenosis

dosing.instructions: 140 mg SC every 2 weeks or 420 mg SC monthly; significant additional LDL lowering (50-60%); use if LDL remains above 70 mg/dL on max statin + ezetimibe

Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: Lipid panel q4-12 weeks; injection site reactions; cost and insurance authorization

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: First-line ACE inhibitor for BP management; target BP <130/80 for symptomatic carotid stenosis (secondary stroke prevention); use caution with severe bilateral carotid stenosis (cerebral perfusion risk if BP drops too low)

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg q1-2wk; target BP <130/80 for symptomatic; <140/90 for asymptomatic (avoid aggressive lowering if bilateral severe stenosis); max 40 mg

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Bilateral renal artery stenosis; angioedema history; pregnancy; hyperkalemia; critical bilateral carotid stenosis with hemodynamic compromise (cautious titration)
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: BMP within 2 weeks (creatinine, potassium); BP; cough (switch to ARB if intolerable)

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: ARB for BP management; alternative if ACE inhibitor not tolerated (cough); LIFE trial showed stroke reduction vs atenolol

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg daily; increase by 25-50 mg q2-4wk; target BP <130/80 (symptomatic) or <140/90 (asymptomatic); max 100 mg

Medical Optimization (All Patients).contraindications: Bilateral renal artery stenosis; pregnancy; hyperkalemia
Medical Optimization (All Patients).monitoring: BMP within 2 weeks; BP; less cough than ACEi

Medical Optimization (All Patients).indication: Calcium channel blocker for BP management; add-on to ACEi/ARB; well tolerated in elderly; evidence from ASCOT trial

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5-5 mg daily; increase by 2.5-5 mg q1-2wk; max 10 mg; well tolerated in elderly

Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.indication: Symptomatic carotid stenosis 70-99% (NASCET: ARR 17% over 2 years; NNT 6); symptomatic 50-69% (NASCET: ARR 6.5%; NNT 15); best benefit within 2 weeks of symptom onset; gold standard revascularization

dosing.instructions: Perform within 2 weeks of index event for maximal benefit (NASCET/ECST data); patch angioplasty closure preferred; conventional or eversion technique; perioperative aspirin; continue statin perioperatively

Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.contraindications: Perioperative stroke/death risk must be <6% for symptomatic (Class I); severe cardiac disease (recent MI <30 days, unstable angina, decompensated HF); contralateral carotid occlusion increases risk; prior radical neck dissection; radiation-induced stenosis (favor CAS)
Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.monitoring: Continuous neuro checks q1h x 24h post-op; BP monitoring (target 100-150 systolic to avoid hyperperfusion syndrome); carotid duplex within 30 days post-op; cranial nerve exam (CN VII, X, XII most common injuries)

Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.indication: Alternative to CEA for symptomatic stenosis >=70% when CEA high risk; CREST showed equivalent outcomes to CEA for symptomatic stenosis (higher periprocedural stroke risk but lower MI risk); preferred when: high surgical risk, prior neck radiation, surgically inaccessible lesion (high bifurcation), restenosis after prior CEA, contralateral CN palsy

dosing.instructions: DAPT required: aspirin 81-325 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg starting 5-7 days pre-procedure or with loading doses; distal embolic protection device mandatory; self-expanding stent preferred; post-dilation to residual <30% stenosis

Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.contraindications: Perioperative stroke/death risk must be <6% for symptomatic; large ischemic core (increased hemorrhagic conversion risk); heavy circumferential calcification (stent expansion may fail); extreme tortuosity of aortic arch/carotid; type III aortic arch; severely diseased aortic arch
Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.monitoring: DAPT compliance; BP monitoring (hypotension from baroreceptor stimulation — may need pressors); post-procedure carotid duplex at 1 month, 6 months, then annually; monitor for in-stent restenosis

Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.indication: Crescendo TIAs (recurrent TIAs despite medical therapy); fluctuating neurologic deficit with severe ipsilateral stenosis; stroke-in-evolution with accessible carotid lesion; timing within 48 hours if neurologically stable

dosing.instructions: Urgent CEA within 48 hours of symptom onset in stable patients; no benefit if large completed infarct (>1/3 MCA territory — delay 4-6 weeks); perioperative BP control critical

Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.contraindications: Large established infarct (hemorrhagic conversion risk); medically unstable (acute MI, severe HF); INR >1.5 (reverse first)
Revascularization (Symptomatic Carotid S.monitoring: Continuous neuro monitoring; ICU post-op with arterial line; frequent neuro checks; BP target 100-150 systolic

Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.indication: Asymptomatic carotid stenosis 60-99% per ACAS/ACST criteria (ARR ~1%/year vs medical therapy); however CREST-2 and contemporary optimal medical therapy may narrow this benefit; strongest indication when: life expectancy >5 years, perioperative risk <3%, and features suggesting higher stroke risk (contralateral occlusion, silent infarcts on MRI, progressive stenosis, microemboli on TCD, ulcerated plaque)

doseOptions.orderSentence: CEA for asymptomatic stenosis N/A Surgical

dosing.instructions: Elective; perioperative risk must be <3% for asymptomatic (Class I); aspirin continued perioperatively; patch angioplasty; risk-benefit discussion with patient
dosing.orderSentence: CEA for asymptomatic stenosis N/A Surgical

Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.contraindications: Life expectancy <5 years; perioperative stroke/death risk >3%; severe cardiac or pulmonary comorbidity; patient preference for medical management after informed discussion
Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.monitoring: Carotid duplex at 1 month, 6 months, annually post-op; neuro checks post-op; cranial nerve exam; lifelong medical optimization continues

Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.indication: Alternative to CEA for asymptomatic stenosis >=70% when high surgical risk; CREST-2 trial data comparing CAS+medical vs medical alone; SAPPHIRE trial showed non-inferiority to CEA in high-risk patients; indicated when: prior neck radiation, surgically inaccessible lesion, restenosis after prior CEA

doseOptions.orderSentence: CAS for asymptomatic stenosis N/A Endovascular

dosing.instructions: DAPT required: aspirin 81-325 mg + clopidogrel 75 mg starting 5-7 days pre-procedure; distal embolic protection device; perioperative stroke/death risk must be <3% for asymptomatic
dosing.orderSentence: CAS for asymptomatic stenosis N/A Endovascular

Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.contraindications: Perioperative risk >3%; heavy calcification; extreme tortuosity; type III arch; life expectancy <5 years
Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.monitoring: DAPT compliance; post-procedure duplex at 1 month, 6 months, annually; monitor for in-stent restenosis; lifelong medical optimization continues

Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.item: Intensive medical therapy alone (for asymptomatic stenosis)
Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.indication: Preferred initial management for most asymptomatic carotid stenosis given contemporary medical therapy effectiveness; annual stroke risk <1% with optimal medical therapy in modern era (vs 2%/year in ACAS era); CREST-2 comparing revascularization + medical vs medical alone

doseOptions.orderSentence: Intensive medical therapy alone (for asymptomatic stenosis) Aspirin 81 mg + statin + antihypertensive PO

dosing.instructions: Aspirin 81 mg daily + high-intensity statin (atorvastatin 40-80 mg or rosuvastatin 20-40 mg) + BP target <140/90; add clopidogrel if high-risk features; aggressive risk factor modification; annual surveillance imaging
dosing.orderSentence: Intensive medical therapy alone (for asymptomatic stenosis) Aspirin 81 mg + statin + antihypertensive PO

Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.contraindications: None (this is baseline management for all patients)
Revascularization (Asymptomatic Carotid.monitoring: Carotid duplex q6-12 months; lipid panel q3-6 months; BP monitoring; progression of stenosis warrants reassessment for intervention

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.indication: Perioperative BP control for CEA/CAS; prevent hyperperfusion syndrome; maintain BP 100-150 systolic post-CEA; rapid onset and easy titration

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg/hr IV infusion; titrate by 2.5 mg/hr every 5-15 minutes; target SBP 100-150 (post-CEA) or per surgeon guidance; max 15 mg/hr; transition to oral antihypertensives when stable

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.contraindications: Severe aortic stenosis; advanced heart failure
Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.monitoring: Continuous arterial line BP; HR; neuro checks q1h; transition to oral agents within 24-48h

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.indication: Alternative perioperative BP control; combined alpha/beta blocker; useful when HR also elevated

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg IV push q10-15min; or infusion 1-2 mg/min; max 300 mg total; target SBP 100-150 post-CEA

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.contraindications: Severe bradycardia; second/third degree heart block; decompensated HF; severe asthma/COPD; cardiogenic shock

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.indication: Post-CEA or post-CAS hypotension from baroreceptor stimulation; more common after CAS (carotid sinus manipulation); maintain cerebral perfusion

dosing.instructions: 40-100 mcg IV bolus q1-2min PRN; or infusion 10-200 mcg/min; titrate to SBP >100 or per clinical status; baroreceptor-mediated hypotension usually self-limited (24-72h)

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.contraindications: Severe hypertension; peripheral vascular disease (digital ischemia); MAO inhibitor use
Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.monitoring: Continuous BP and HR via arterial line; I/O; end-organ perfusion; typically wean within 24-72h

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.indication: Post-CAS bradycardia from baroreceptor stimulation during stent deployment; prophylactic or reactive

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg IV push; may repeat q3-5min; max 3 mg; prophylactic 0.5 mg IV before CAS balloon inflation in some protocols

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.monitoring: HR; BP; urinary retention; rarely needed beyond procedural period

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.indication: Intraoperative anticoagulation during CEA (prevent clamp thrombosis) and CAS (prevent catheter/stent thrombosis); standard of care

dosing.instructions: 5000-10000 units IV bolus before carotid clamping (CEA) or before catheter advancement (CAS); target ACT >250; protamine reversal at surgeon discretion post-CEA

Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.contraindications: Active major hemorrhage; HIT (use bivalirudin alternative)
Perioperative and Post-Procedural Manage.monitoring: ACT intraoperatively; post-op drain output (CEA); bleeding from access site (CAS)

Referrals & Consults.item: Vascular surgery or vascular neurosurgery referral for CEA evaluation in all symptomatic carotid stenosis >=50% and asymptomatic stenosis >=60% with life expectancy >5 years
Neurointerventional surgery referral for CAS evaluation when CEA is high-risk (prior neck radiation, surgically inaccessible lesion, restenosis after prior CEA, contralateral CN palsy)
Neurology follow-up in 1-2 weeks post-event for symptomatic carotid stenosis; medication optimization, imaging review, and secondary prevention management; then q3-6 months
Cardiology referral for preoperative cardiac risk stratification before CEA/CAS; concurrent coronary artery disease evaluation; AF management if detected; EF assessment
Anesthesiology preoperative evaluation for CEA surgical planning; regional vs general anesthesia discussion; cardiac risk assessment
Physical therapy for gait training and fall prevention if post-stroke residual deficits from symptomatic carotid stenosis event
Occupational therapy for ADL retraining and upper extremity function if post-stroke deficits from symptomatic carotid stenosis event
Speech-language pathology for aphasia, dysarthria, or swallow evaluation if post-stroke deficits from symptomatic carotid event
Endocrinology referral for diabetes management optimization if HbA1c >8% despite standard therapy; aggressive glycemic control reduces atherosclerosis progression

Smoking cessation program referral with pharmacotherapy support (varenicline, bupropion, or nicotine replacement); smoking is the single most modifiable risk factor for carotid atherosclerosis progression

Patient Instructions.item: Learn and recognize stroke warning signs (FAST: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911); call 911 immediately if any symptom occurs — do not wait to see if symptoms resolve

Take all medications as prescribed including aspirin, statin, and blood pressure medications every day; DO NOT stop antiplatelet medication without consulting your neurologist or surgeon — stopping these medications significantly increases stroke risk
If scheduled for CEA or CAS, take aspirin the morning of surgery unless told otherwise; inform your surgeon of all blood thinners including over-the-counter medications and supplements

After CEA surgery, report immediately: new weakness, numbness, speech difficulty, vision changes, severe headache, neck swelling, or difficulty breathing (may indicate stroke, neck hematoma, or hyperperfusion syndrome)
After CAS procedure, report immediately: new neurologic symptoms, groin swelling or bleeding at catheter site, chest pain, or severe headache
Monitor blood pressure at home twice daily (morning and evening) using validated automatic cuff; keep a log and bring to all appointments; target <130/80 if symptomatic, <140/90 if asymptomatic
Attend all scheduled follow-up carotid ultrasound appointments; surveillance imaging detects progression or restenosis early when intervention is most effective
Do not drive until cleared by your neurologist if you have had a TIA or stroke; driving restrictions vary by state but typically require 3-6 months seizure-free and stable neurologically

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation is the single most important lifestyle modification for carotid stenosis; reduces progression of atherosclerosis and perioperative complications; offer nicotine replacement, varenicline, or bupropion; referral to cessation program

Mediterranean-style or DASH diet: rich in fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, olive oil; limit sodium to <2300 mg/day (1500 mg if hypertensive); limit processed foods and red meat; dietary pattern reduces atherosclerosis progression

Regular aerobic exercise: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise (brisk walking, swimming, cycling) at least 5 days per week; exercise improves endothelial function and reduces cardiovascular events by 20-25%
Limit alcohol to <=1 drink/day for women, <=2 drinks/day for men; heavy alcohol consumption increases blood pressure and stroke risk; complete abstinence preferred if poorly controlled hypertension
Weight management: target BMI 18.5-25; waist circumference <40 inches (men) / <35 inches (women); even modest weight loss (5-10%) improves blood pressure, lipids, and glucose control
Diabetes management: target HbA1c <7% (individualize for elderly); strict glycemic control slows carotid intima-media thickness progression; regular glucose monitoring and medication adherence

Stress management and adequate sleep (7-9 hours nightly); chronic stress and sleep deprivation contribute to hypertension and atherosclerosis; screen for obstructive sleep apnea (STOP-BANG questionnaire)

differential.features: Stenosis of intracranial arteries (MCA, basilar, intracranial ICA); different treatment approach (SAMMPRIS showed medical > stenting for intracranial stenosis); may coexist with extracranial disease
differential.tests: CTA/MRA head (intracranial vessels); TCD with intracranial velocities; distinguish from extracranial disease on vascular imaging

differential.features: Younger patients; history of trauma or neck manipulation; sudden headache or neck pain; Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis); mural hematoma on imaging; not atherosclerotic
differential.tests: CTA/MRA neck (intramural hematoma, string sign, dissection flap); fat-saturated T1 MRI neck (crescent sign); typically anticoagulate or antiplatelet rather than revascularize

differential.features: Younger women; "string of beads" appearance on imaging; may affect renal arteries concurrently; non-atherosclerotic; higher dissection risk
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (beaded appearance); screen for renal FMD; genetic counseling; antiplatelet therapy; rarely requires surgical intervention

differential.features: Young women (<40); large vessel vasculitis; systemic inflammation (elevated ESR/CRP); may cause carotid stenosis or occlusion; pulses absent or diminished
differential.tests: ESR, CRP (elevated); CTA/MRA (long-segment stenosis, wall thickening); PET/CT (active inflammation); treat with immunosuppression not surgical revascularization in active phase

differential.features: Age >50; headache; jaw claudication; PMR symptoms; elevated ESR/CRP; can cause extracranial carotid and vertebral stenosis
differential.tests: ESR (>50), CRP; temporal artery biopsy; CTA/MRA (long-segment smooth stenosis vs focal atherosclerotic plaque); treat with high-dose steroids

differential.features: History of prior head/neck radiation therapy; delayed stenosis years-decades after radiation; diffuse and often long-segment stenosis; higher restenosis rates; CAS often preferred over CEA
differential.tests: Clinical history of prior radiation; CTA/MRA (long-segment stenosis in radiation field); tissue fibrosis makes CEA technically difficult; CAS preferred

differential.features: Thin shelf-like intraluminal filling defect; typically at posterior wall of carotid bulb; young patient with cryptogenic stroke; not true atherosclerotic stenosis
differential.tests: CTA neck with thin cuts (shelf-like filling defect at posterior bulb); often missed on ultrasound; treatment: antiplatelet vs surgical web resection for recurrent events

differential.features: Pulsatile neck mass; splaying of ICA and ECA on imaging ("lyre sign"); may cause compression or displacement of carotid but not atherosclerotic stenosis
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (enhancing mass at carotid bifurcation with vessel splaying); plasma metanephrines; surgical excision if symptomatic

differential.features: AF or structural heart disease as primary stroke etiology; carotid imaging shows <50% stenosis; embolic infarct pattern on MRI; treatment is anticoagulation not CEA
differential.tests: ECG, Holter, echocardiogram (AF, LV thrombus, valvular vegetation); carotid duplex (<50% stenosis); management with anticoagulation rather than antiplatelet/revascularization

evidence.recommendation: CEA for symptomatic carotid stenosis 70-99% reduces ipsilateral stroke risk (ARR 17% at 2 years; NNT 6)
CEA benefit in symptomatic 50-69% stenosis is moderate (ARR 6.5% at 5 years) and greatest in men, recent events, and hemisphere symptoms
CEA for symptomatic stenosis confirmed in European trial with different measurement method
CEA for asymptomatic stenosis >=60% reduces 5-year stroke risk (ARR 5.9%; NNT 17); benefit requires perioperative risk <3%
CEA for asymptomatic stenosis >=60% confirmed in larger European trial (ARR 5.4% at 5 years)
CAS non-inferior to CEA for symptomatic and asymptomatic stenosis at 4 years (composite endpoint); CAS higher periprocedural stroke, CEA higher periprocedural MI
CREST long-term follow-up (10 years) showed equivalent outcomes between CEA and CAS for symptomatic patients; age interaction (younger patients do better with CAS, older with CEA)
Maximum benefit of CEA occurs when performed within 2 weeks of symptomatic event; delay reduces benefit significantly
evidence.evidenceLevel: Class I, Level A (Pooled RCT analysis)

evidence.recommendation: DAPT (aspirin + clopidogrel) x 21 days for minor stroke/high-risk TIA reduces recurrent stroke
evidence.source: [Wang et al. NEJM 2013 (CHANCE)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23803136/); [Johnston et al. NEJM 2018 (POINT)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29766750/)

evidence.recommendation: High-intensity statin with LDL <70 for secondary stroke prevention reduces recurrent vascular events
evidence.source: [Amarenco et al. NEJM 2006 (SPARCL)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16899775/); [Amarenco et al. NEJM 2020 (TST)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31738483/)

evidence.recommendation: BP target <130/80 for secondary stroke prevention (symptomatic patients)
AHA/ASA guideline for management of extracranial carotid and vertebral artery disease — comprehensive practice guideline
Society for Vascular Surgery guidelines for management of extracranial carotid stenosis
Microembolic signals on TCD predict increased stroke risk in asymptomatic carotid stenosis
Intraplaque hemorrhage on MRI predicts ipsilateral cerebrovascular events in carotid stenosis
CAS with embolic protection non-inferior to CEA in high-risk surgical patients
Mediterranean diet reduces recurrent cardiovascular events
PCSK9 inhibitor (evolocumab) reduces cardiovascular events in patients with atherosclerotic disease on statin therapy

monitoring.frequency: 1 month post-CEA/CAS, 6 months, then annually; q6-12 months if unoperated significant stenosis
monitoring.action: Progressive stenosis >80% or new symptoms warrants repeat intervention evaluation; in-stent restenosis >70% warrants angiography

monitoring.frequency: Home BID; each clinic visit; continuous post-CEA/CAS x 24h
monitoring.action: Add/increase antihypertensives; caution with bilateral stenosis (avoid excessive lowering); post-op: treat >160 aggressively (hyperperfusion risk); treat <90 with pressors (cerebral hypoperfusion)

monitoring.frequency: 6 weeks after statin start; q3-6 months until goal; annually
monitoring.action: Intensify statin; add ezetimibe; add PCSK9 inhibitor if still above goal despite max statin + ezetimibe

monitoring.frequency: q3 months until <7%; then q6 months
monitoring.action: Intensify diabetes treatment; add second agent; endocrine referral if HbA1c >8%

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit; q1h x 24h post-CEA/CAS; at any acute change
monitoring.action: New deficit post-op warrants emergent imaging (CT head + CTA neck) to evaluate for thrombosis, embolism, or hyperperfusion syndrome; if within 6h consider re-exploration

monitoring.frequency: Immediately post-op; daily until discharge; each clinic visit x 3 months
monitoring.action: CN injury in 5-8% of CEA; most resolve in 6-12 weeks; persistent CN X palsy warrants ENT evaluation and swallow assessment; bilateral CN X injury is emergency

monitoring.frequency: 2 weeks after ACEi/ARB start; after contrast procedures; q6 months
monitoring.action: Cr rise >30% warrants evaluation; post-contrast AKI: hydration, hold metformin; K >5.5 warrants reduction of ACEi/ARB

monitoring.frequency: Daily during hospitalization; 1-2 weeks post-op; any acute neck swelling
monitoring.action: Expanding neck hematoma warrants emergent surgical exploration (airway compromise risk); wound infection warrants antibiotics and possible drainage
Nutritional counseling; exercise prescription; medication review for weight-gaining medications

disposition.criteria: Asymptomatic carotid stenosis found incidentally; TIA with resolved symptoms AND completed urgent workup (duplex, MRI, labs) AND no high-grade stenosis requiring admission; established outpatient follow-up within 1-2 weeks arranged

Symptomatic carotid stenosis (TIA or stroke) with >=50% ipsilateral stenosis for expedited workup and revascularization planning; post-CEA/CAS routine recovery (typically 1-2 days); crescendo TIAs requiring urgent intervention

Post-CEA/CAS with hemodynamic instability (refractory hypotension or hypertension); post-CEA neck hematoma requiring monitoring or re-exploration; hyperperfusion syndrome (severe headache, seizure, ICH post-revascularization); stroke-in-evolution with unstable neurologic exam

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Symptomatic high-grade carotid stenosis at facility without CEA/CAS capability; post-CEA complication requiring neurointerventional or neurosurgical expertise not available locally

Neurologically stable for >24h; cranial nerves intact or documented and stable; BP controlled on oral medications; wound hemostatic; tolerating diet; follow-up arranged (1-2 weeks surgical, 4 weeks duplex)

Neurologically stable; groin access site hemostatic and no pseudoaneurysm; BP stable; DAPT compliance confirmed and understood; follow-up arranged (1 month duplex, neurology/interventionalist follow-up in 2-4 weeks)

Neurology/vascular surgery 1-2 weeks post-event or post-procedure; carotid duplex at 1 month, 6 months, then annually; PCP q1-3 months for risk factor management; lipid panel q3-6 months until at goal
